dt: {bc}to clear from alleged fault or guilt

pt: {sc}exculpate{/sc} {sc}absolve{/sc} {sc}exonerate{/sc} {sc}acquit{/sc} {sc}vindicate{/sc} mean to free from a charge. {sc}exculpate{/sc} implies a clearing from blame or fault often in a matter of small importance.

pt.t: {it}exculpating{/it} himself from the charge of overenthusiasm

pt: {sc}absolve{/sc} implies a release either from an obligation that binds the conscience or from the consequences of disobeying the law or committing a sin.
{sc}exonerate{/sc} implies a complete clearance from an accusation or charge and from any attendant suspicion of blame or guilt.
{sc}acquit{/sc} implies a formal decision in one's favor with respect to a definite charge.

{sc}vindicate{/sc} may refer to things as well as persons that have been subjected to critical attack or imputation of guilt, weakness, or folly, and implies a clearing effected by proving the unfairness of such criticism or blame.

et: Medieval Latin {it}exculpatus{/it}, past participle of {it}exculpare{/it}, from Latin {it}ex-{/it} + {it}culpa{/it} blame
shortdef: to clear from alleged fault or guilt
